# Terminology
<img src='data:image/png;base64,'>

--

## Do _not_ use "to crypt"

--

## To _Cipher_ and To _Decipher_
### When it's possible to go both ways
Note: When you need a key

--

## üá´üá∑ Chiffrer et D√©chiffrer ü•ñ

--

## Plaintext ‚ÜîÔ∏è Ciphertext

--

## To _hash_
### (there's no "dehash")

--

## To _decrypt_ can be used...
### when you try to _break_ a cipher


## Various types of ciphering


# _Symmetric_ Ciphering

--

# The _same key_ is used to cipher and to decipher

--

<img src='https://i.imgur.com/xrZ9ujA.png'>

--

## This is known as the _PSK_
### (<em>P</em>re-<em>S</em>hared <em>K</em>ey)

--

## Exemples
### AES, DES, Caesar Cipher (üòÇ)

--

# Cons
### You need to find a way to send the key in a _secure manner_ to the other party

--

# Pros
### it is way _faster_ than asymmetric algorithm.<br />Most of the time, it's just a XOR.
#### (and cpus love xors)


# _Asymmetric_ ciphering

--

# _Public_ key

--

# It's _public_
_Everyone_ can see it. It is <span style='color:red'>**not**</span> a secret, and should not be handled as one.

--

# _Private_ key

--

# It's _private_
It should be _protected_ with the <span style='color:red'>**highest level of security**</span>.
Note: More on that later

--

<small>_(most of the time)_</small><br />
The **public key** is used to **cipher**,<br />
the **private key** is used to **decipher**.

--

<img src='https://sectigostore.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/types-of-encryption-asymmetric-encryption.png' />

--

# How does it works?

--

### It's _complicated_
<img src='https://i.imgur.com/aADVTFA.png' />

### But let's try anyway

--

# Basically :
## _Multiplicating_ two numbers is _easy_

--

A computer can do<br />`404780794865292901437549558619 x 353552160741801626507321536189` **very fast**.<br />
<small>(That's `143111124651408266345913491480290945155891123020409985362991`)</small>

--

## _Factoring_ is _HARD_
Starting from `143111124651408266345913491480290945155891123020409985362991`,<br />
find the two previous primes.

--

<img src='https://media.istockphoto.com/photos/how-did-that-happen-picture-id1157966362?k=20&m=1157966362&s=612x612&w=0&h=OtWLSAdpUkNdzG4c4y2oFbZPw1HnppLQHBor6vTBlB8='>

--

## What about _quantum_ computing?

--

### It's _hard_ for them too.

<code class='hljs'>
Taking this into account dramatically increases the resources required to factor 2048-bit numbers. In 2015, researchers estimated that a quantum computer would need <strong>a billion qubits</strong> to do the job reliably. That‚Äôs significantly more than <strong>the 70 qubits</strong> in today‚Äôs state-of-the-art quantum computers.<br />
On that basis, security experts might well have been able to justify the idea that it would be <strong>decades</strong> before messages with 2048-bit RSA encryption could be broken by a quantum computer.
</code>

<small>[Source (technologyreview.com)](https://www.technologyreview.com/2019/05/30/65724/how-a-quantum-computer-could-break-2048-bit-rsa-encryption-in-8-hours/)</small>


# Digital Signature

--

## A signature is a _private key_ cipher of a _hash_ of the message

--

## What?

--

## You take your _message_<br />`m`

--

## You compute its _hash_<br />`sha256(m)`

--

## You _cipher_ that has using<br /> your _private key_<br />`rsa(sha256(m), private-key)`

--

## You append that to the original message
<code class='hljs'><pre>
{
    message: m,
    signature: rsa(sha256(m), private-key),
}
</pre></code>
## You've got a _signature_ !

--

Usually you use a lib that does that for you

--

<small>Do not implement cryptography from scratch, kids</small>

--

## A digital signature _provides_
- ‚úÖ Authentification
- ‚úÖ Non-Repudiation
- ‚ùå Confidentiality
Note: Anyone can read the message


# How to _handle_ a private key

--

## A private key should _never leave_ the machine where it is generated

--

## If the private key is _transfered_ over a network, it is <span style="color:red">compromised</span> and should be replaced

<img src='https://i.imgur.com/qHMxx5Y.png'>

--

## What is if the machine needs to be _replaced_?

--

# The exception :
## _Private Key Wrapping_

--

* On the receiver machine, generate a new key pair "B"
* Transfer the public key "B" to the donor machine
* Encrypt the private key "A" with the public key "B"
* Transfer the newly encrypted private key B(A) in the donor machine
Note: TODO: make a diagram ?

--

# Private Key _Passphrase_

--

## You can _encrypt_ your private key using a passphrase

--

## It uses _Symmetrical_ Cryptography
### (128-bit AES)

--

## If someone _access_ your computer, it's _better_ if your key is encrypted

--

### (you should _still rotate_ your private key afterwards)


## "But my key can be read from my computer _memory_...

--

## ...and on the _disk_...

--

## ...what if I have a _keylogger_?

--

# HSM

--

# HSM
## <em>H</em>ardware <em>S</em>ecurity <em>M</em>odule

--

<img src='https://cpl.thalesgroup.com/sites/default/files/content/paragraphs_type/image_with_col/2020-06/SafeNet-Luna-Network-HSM_0.png' /><br />
<img src='https://i.imgur.com/IypyKWD.png' /><br />
<img src='https://5.imimg.com/data5/RU/FP/MY-2994193/smart-card-500x500.jpg' />
Note: some are expensive, some are not

--

## A HSM _never reveal_ its private key

--

## You can ask it to do things _with_ the key for you

--

* Generate a new key
* Encrypt
* Decrypt
* Sign
* Verify Signature
* More complex things (small scripts)

--

## But you <span style="color:red">cannot</span> ask it<br />to _tell you_ its key


# AWS KMS

--

# AWS KMS
## AWS <em>K</em>ey <em>M</em>anagement <em>S</em>ervice

--

# Basically
## HSM _As A Service_

--

## Uses _AWS API_ to interact with the keys


## If this is relevant to you :

- DH (diffie-helmann)
- How SSL works (session key, RSA AES...)
- How certificates works (https...)
Note: I can talk about theses things
